Wait, but in Fortran, when you use write with a format, you need to have the correct format. For example, when writing two integers, the format could be (2I0) but then separated by a space. Alternatively, '(I0, " ", I0)' as used above.

But let me check: for m=3, i=5, the string would be '3 5' which is correct.

But when writing to a character variable, the length of the variable must be sufficient. For example, if m and i are up to 10^5, then each integer could be up to 5 or 6 digits. So using len=20 should suffice. But in the code above, when allocating r as 2n elements, each of len=20. So the code would need to have:

character(len=20), allocatable :: r(:)

Then, when writing to r(cnt), it would be filled up to the required length.

Another thing: when the code reads the array a, the Java code uses Arrays.setAll(a, i -> s.nextInt()); which reads n integers. In Fortran, read(*,*) a reads all the integers on the same line or subsequent lines. So assuming that the input is provided as a single line for the array. If the input has the array elements split across lines, this may not work, but per typical programming contest inputs, it's likely that the array is given on a single line after n.

Another point: the Java code's first part loops through all elements, including m itself. But when i = m, the condition (a[m] >=0 XOR a[i] >=0) is false, so no operation is added. So in Fortran, the loop from 1 to n includes m, but the condition will skip it. So that's okay.
